feed.title: NewsTracker: ferguson
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Ferguson voters go to polls to elect 3 City Council members
entry.summary: In this photo made in March 2015, Ferguson Ward 3 city council candidate Wesley Bell poses for a portrait in Ferguson, Mo.

entry.title: Ferguson voters go to polls to elect 3 City Council members
entry.summary: (AP) - The next Ferguson City Council will face the daunting task of remaking much of the beleaguered town's leadership, a process that will begin soon after Tuesday's municipal election.

entry.title: Ferguson voters, black candidates to make history in council election
entry.summary:
Voters in Ferguson, Missouri, go to the polls on Tuesday with an opportunity to transform the city's political fabric and put as many as three African Americans on the City Council for the first time in the city's history.

Protesters thronged the city, claiming Ferguson's majority-white police force harassed black residents while the city's white politicians did nothing.

Former Ferguson resident Tammy Hawkins, who is black and not related to candidate Adrienne Hawkins, said she has little faith in an election to change the city's character.

The civic unrest inspired Bob Hudgins, who is white, to challenge former Ferguson mayor Brian Fletcher for a seat representing Ward 2 on the council.

entry.title: FBI investigating 2 attacks with alleged Ferguson references
Pair of Ferguson-area incidents investigated by FBI as hate crimes
entry.summary: Police said Street, who is white, shouted racial slurs and told Ford, who is black, "Go back to Ferguson."

entry.title: Ferguson releases racist emails cited by Justice Department
entry.summary: Los Angeles: Police and a city official in Ferguson, Missouri, sent racially charged emails comparing minority welfare recipients to dogs and made insensitive comments about Muslims, copies of the emails released by the city show.

entry.title: Focus in Ferguson shifts to election of City Council members
Quick answers to double shooting elude police in Ferguson, Missouri
entry.summary: To that end, five residents signed an affidavit at Ferguson City Hall Friday afternoon to start a petition for Mayor James Knowles' recall, according to a statement from The Organization for Black Struggle.

entry.title: Focus in Ferguson shifts to election of City Council members
entry.summary: In this photo made Friday, April 3, 2015, Reginald Rounds, a volunteer with the Organization for Black Struggle, stops to check his map and voter rolls while canvassing a neighborhood in Ferguson, Mo.

entry.title: Focus in Ferguson shifts to election of City Council members
entry.summary: In this photo made Friday, April 3, 2015, campaign literature sits on a table as volunteers prepare to canvass a neighborhood urging residents to vote in Ferguson, Mo.

entry.title: Focus in Ferguson shifts to election of City Council members
entry.summary:
Ferguson staggers elections for three-year terms, so three council members and Mayor James Knowles III are not facing election this year.

"This election is about winning justice for residents of Ferguson," said Dan Cantor, national director of Working Families Party, which helped elect New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio last year.

Just 12.3 percent of Ferguson's registered voters went to the polls in April 2014, said Eric Fey, director of elections for St. Louis County.

entry.title: Ferguson, Missouri, releases racist emails from former officials
entry.summary: The emails, although dating back years before the shooting, were among evidence presented by the Justice Department in a report in March that concluded that racism pervaded the Ferguson Police Department.

entry.title: Ferguson, Missouri, releases racist emails from former officials
entry.summary:
They were sent and received by Mary Ann Twitty, who was Ferguson's court clerk, as well as former Ferguson police Captain Rick Henke and former police Sergeant William Mudd.

Ferguson Mayor James Knowles condemned the emails when the Justice Department report was released, saying, "These actions taken by these individuals are in no way representative of the employees of the city of Ferguson."

entry.title: Ferguson releases racist emails from clerk to 2 officers
entry.summary: (AP) - Racist emails released Friday by the city of Ferguson indicate most were sent by a former city court clerk to two police officers, and there's no indication other city employees were involved.

entry.title: Ferguson releases racist emails from clerk to 2 officers
2 Men Accused of Bomb Plot During Ferguson Protests
2 St. Louis men accused of plot to obtain bombs for use during Ferguson protests
entry.summary: The indictment says the men were arrested in November, about a week before prosecutors announced they wouldn't charge the white Ferguson police officer who last summer fatally shot 18-year-old Michael Brown, who was black and unarmed.

entry.title: Ferguson, Missouri police menaced African-American citizens for revenue, US federal investigation concludes
entry.summary:
Addressing reporters in Washington, DC, the Attorney General, Eric Holder, said many in Ferguson might be mistaken about the circumstances surrounding the shooting, but given the practices of the police and the city, he understood their anger and mistrust.

A police tactical team moves in to disperse protesters in Ferguson, Missouri, in August 2014.

The report shows that 85 per cent of people subject to vehicle stops by Ferguson police were African-American; 90 percent of those who received citations were black; and 93 percent of people arrested were black.

Last month the St Louis County Prosecutor Bob McCulloch decried Ferguson's practice of filling public coffers through ticketing as immoral.

entry.title: Ferguson police chief stays on the job after federal report
entry.summary: Attorney General Eric Holder told reporters Friday that the federal government will "use all the power that we have to change the situation" in Ferguson, including possibly dismantling the police force.

entry.title: ACTU turns its back on Ferguson
entry.summary: "Martin is doing what Martin is paid to do," ACTU secretary Dave Oliver told ABC radio, describing Mr Ferguson as a well-paid mouthpiece for the mining sector.

entry.title: Man Accused in Ferguson Police Shooting Denied Lower Bond
entry.summary: A Missouri judge on Tuesday refused to reduce the bond of a 20-year-old man accused of shooting and wounding two police officers during a Ferguson protest, despite an attorney's insistence that the man was beaten by police into wrongly confessing.

entry.title: Mats Hummels 'gave his word' to Sir Alex Ferguson he WILL join Manchester United!
Man accused in Ferguson police shooting to seek lower bond
entry.summary: FILE - In this March 12, 2015, file photo, Police shine a light on a helmet as they investigate the scene where two police officers were shot outside the Ferguson Police Department in Ferguson, Mo.

entry.title: Man accused in Ferguson police shooting to seek lower bond
4 journalists arrested during Ferguson protests sue police
Scathing report finds patterns of racial bias in Ferguson
entry.summary: A boy walks past a memorial for Michael Brown, who was shot and killed by Ferguson, Mo., Police Officer Darren Wilson last summer, in Ferguson, Mo., Tuesday, March 3, 2015.

entry.title: No ill feelings toward Ferguson: Raiders
entry.summary:
While Nu'uausala might still hold strong connections with his old club, the same can't be said for Ferguson and the Raiders.

After a year of exile in 2014, Sunday will be the first time Ferguson faces his old club and comes just a week after starring in the Roosters' win over Penrith.

entry.title: No ill feelings toward Ferguson: Raiders
entry.summary: Ferguson spectacularly went AWOL from the Raiders in 2013 after a string of off-field indiscretions, leaving the club no choice but to sack the rising star just after he had played in a NSW State of Origin side.

entry.title: Robinson says Ferguson's ready for Raiders
entry.summary: Fresh from his two-try heroics against Penrith on Monday night, Ferguson confronts his past when he faces the Raiders for the first time since being sacked by the club in 2013.

entry.title: Settlement reached in lawsuit filed by Ferguson protesters
entry.summary: Protesters sued over the "unified command" that handled security at the protests sparked by the fatal police shooting of 18-year-old Michael Brown in Ferguson in August.

entry.title: Candidate's comparison of Fort Wayne to Ferguson draws heat
Candidate clarifies comparison of Fort Wayne to Ferguson
entry.summary:
Richard Stevenson, a township trustee challenging incumbent Mayor Tom Henry in the Democratic primary, said "there is a lot of similarity between Fort Wayne and Ferguson" during a candidates' forum Saturday at the Fort Wayne Urban League.

City Safety Director and former Police Chief Rusty York called any comparison between Fort Wayne and Ferguson "reckless and unfortunate."

entry.title: Lawyer: Police shooting suspect didn't fire gun in Ferguson
entry.summary: But a separate DOJ report found widespread racial bias in Ferguson's policing and in a municipal court system, which it said was driven by profit mostly extracted from black and low-income residents.

entry.title: Lawyer: Police shooting suspect didn't fire gun in Ferguson
entry.summary: Jeffrey L. Williams, 20, is accused of shooting and wounding the officers on March 12, during an early-morning rally sparked by the resignation of Ferguson's police chief.

entry.title: Ferguson City Council appoints interim city manager
entry.summary:
KSDK-TV (http://on.ksdk.com/1FUcpdY ) reports the Ferguson City Council voted Tuesday night to appoint Pam Hylton to temporarily replace John Shaw.

Six Ferguson officials, including Shaw, have resigned or been fired since the report was released.

entry.title: Trial set for videographer arrested covering Ferguson
entry.summary: Missouri's online court reporting system does not show state charges against any of the arrested journalists, but Ferguson city charges would not appear there.

entry.title: Trial set for videographer arrested covering Ferguson
entry.summary:
Moore was charged with municipal violations after an arrest on Oct. 3., while covering a demonstration outside Ferguson police headquarters.

(AP) - A video journalist arrested while covering the unrest in Ferguson, Missouri, after Michael Brown was fatally shot last summer plans to fight the charges at trial.

entry.title: Labor's Ferguson praises Baird's courage
entry.summary: Mr Ferguson even seemed to liken Mr Baird to former Labor prime minister Gough Whitlam.

entry.title: Robinson pleased with Ferguson progress
entry.summary:
Ferguson crossed for two second-half tries in Monday's 20-12 win over Penrith - his first scores for the club in only his third game since ending his exile from the game following his sacking by Canberra in 2013.

Ferguson spoke on Sunday about his desire to put his wild ways behind him and, with a child on the way, is fully aware of the consequences that will follow should he mess up off the field again.

Skipper Pearce said Ferguson's slotted in well with the rest of the squad since his arrival and his defensive efforts were more impressive than his two tries.

entry.title: Ferguson inspires Roosters to Penrith win
entry.summary: Ferguson crossed twice in the second half - his first scores for the club - as the Roosters bounced back from last week's defeat to South Sydney.

entry.title: Ferguson inspires Roosters to Penrith win
entry.summary: Two Blake Ferguson tries helped the Sydney Roosters to a 20-12 victory over Penrith on Monday but once again a refereeing howler was at the centre of attention at Allianz Stadium.

entry.title: Ferguson grateful for his second chance
entry.summary: Ferguson admits the experience has been difficult and is doing his best to stay on the straight and narrow.

entry.title: Ferguson grateful for his second chance
entry.summary:
"It was pretty tough, I lost something that I really enjoyed," Ferguson said on Sunday.

Ferguson's troubles with alcohol and a difficult upbringing have been well documented and the 25-year-old knows it's something he'll continue to battle.

It's been two months since Ferguson last had a drink and although the Roosters have not ordered him to stay dry, he's determined to live his life in a more responsible manner.

entry.title: Ferguson municipal court resumes with new judge
entry.summary:
Richter, who was also given the power to overhaul court practices in Ferguson, issued an order Wednesday barring cameras from the courtroom in response to heavy media interest.

It also faulted Ferguson for issuing an excessive number of arrest warrants when traffic-court offenders failed to pay their fines on time or missed court dates, with relatively minor violations then leading to jail time.

"I don't see any discernible difference," said Michael-John Voss of the Arch City Defenders, a nonprofit legal clinic that is suing Ferguson and the adjacent town of Jennings over their municipal court practices.

entry.title: Man who threatened Ferguson officer must stay off Facebook
Ferguson municipal court resumes with new judge after DOJ report found problems with system
entry.summary:
Beck said an assistant Ferguson city prosecutor dismissed the ticket after she showed proof of insurance.

The federal report said Ferguson was counting on revenues from fines and fees to generate $3.1 million, or nearly one-quarter of its total $13.3 million budget for the 2015 fiscal year.

Local attorneys said they're optimistic that Richter's appointment will spur change not only in Ferguson's court system but also in the 80 other municipal courts spread across St. Louis County.

entry.title: Ferguson Facebook case part of debate about online threats
Starbucks joins the race debate as clashes in Ferguson and elsewhere escalate tension
Ferguson police shooting suspect returns to court
entry.summary:
About 100 pro-police demonstrators stand hold signs outside the Ferguson Police Department as the shadows of counter demonstrators are seen on the street Sunday, March 15, 2015, in Ferguson, Mo.

Protester Maldon Moffitt points his fingers and yells back at a pro-police demonstrator outside the Ferguson Police Department Sunday, March 15, 2015, in Ferguson, Mo.

entry.title: Man accused of shooting two Ferguson cops was 'beaten in custody': Lawyer claims police left him with welts on his face, neck, back and shoulders but stopped him taking photos of the injuries
entry.summary: The lawsuit names Ferguson, St. Louis County, the chiefs of both departments and other officers as defendants.

entry.title: Attorney for Ferguson suspect: Officers shot 'accidentally'
entry.summary: (AP) - A man accused of shooting two police officers in Ferguson returned to court Tuesday over a claim that St. Louis County police used excessive force during his arrest.

entry.title: Attorney for Ferguson suspect: Officers shot 'accidentally'
Ferguson police deny beating suspect
Attorney: Ferguson shooting suspect didn't target officers
entry.summary:
(AP) - A man accused of shooting two officers last week in Ferguson was not targeting police or aiming at demonstrators at a late-night protest, his attorney said Monday as he countered an earlier police description of the crime.

But Ferguson activist Derrick Robinson said Sunday that Williams told him during a jail visit that he had been robbed earlier on the day of the shooting and returned to the protest zone to retaliate.

entry.title: Suspect in Ferguson shooting of police appears in court
entry.summary: The shooting of the officers followed a flurry of resignations and protests in the week after the U.S. Justice Department released a damning report accusing Ferguson of racially biased policing.

entry.title: Accused Ferguson shooter said he was aiming at someone else, authorities say
Suspect charged in shooting of Ferguson, Missouri, police officers
entry.summary: The Justice Department report said Ferguson police overwhelmingly arrested and issued traffic citations to black residents to boost city coffers through fines.

entry.title: Suspect charged in shooting of police officers in Ferguson, Missouri
entry.summary:
(Reuters) - A 20-year-old man was charged on Sunday with first-degree assault in last week's shooting of two policemen during a protest rally in Ferguson, Missouri, a crime that shocked a city that has been devastated by months of racial strife.

The gunfire rang out just after midnight at the end of a rally to call for sweeping reforms in Ferguson, where an unarmed black 18-year-old was shot to death by a white officer last summer.

entry.title: Ferguson police shooting suspect arrested, charged
entry.summary: - A 20-year-old man charged Sunday with shooting two police officers watching over a demonstration outside the Ferguson Police Department had attended a protest there earlier that night but told investigators he wasn't targeting the officers, authorities said.

entry.title: Ferguson: suspect arrested in shooting of police officers
entry.summary: Clayton, Missouri: A 20-year-old man has been charged with first-degree assault in the shooting of two police officers in front of the Ferguson Police Department prosecuting attorney for St Louis County Robert McCulloch said..

entry.title: Ferguson: suspect arrested in shooting of police officers
entry.summary: The shootings took place just hours after Ferguson's police chief resigned in the wake of a scathing US Justice Department report finding his force was rife with racial bias.

entry.title: St. Louis county officials announce arrest in shooting of police officers in Ferguson
entry.summary: But several activists who've been involved in the protests since the Aug. 9 fatal shooting of 18-year-old Michael Brown by a Ferguson police officer told The Associated Press they were not familiar with Williams.

entry.title: Quick answers to double shooting elude police in Ferguson, Missouri
Part-time Ferguson mayor in full-time spotlight
entry.summary:
He argues that Ferguson's city manager form of government made him more figurehead than administrator, leading the city council but lacking the power to do much else.

But he was little known outside the area until Aug. 9, when Officer Darren Wilson shot 18-year-old Michael Brown and Ferguson found itself suddenly in the national spotlight.

After the shooting, Knowles and Police Chief Tom Jackson became the public face of Ferguson, holding news conferences, hosting public forums and reaching out to civil rights leaders and protesters.

entry.title: Part-time Ferguson mayor in full-time spotlight
entry.summary:
Despite calls for him to go, Knowles is the last man standing in Ferguson city government after a Justice Department report highly critical of the city's police force and court system prompted six officials to resign.

(AP) - In the days since the release of a Justice Department report that found widespread racial bias in the Ferguson Police Department, the mayor of the St. Louis suburb has become a part-time public servant in a full-time spotlight.

entry.title: Looted Ferguson Store to Be Transformed Into Training Center
entry.summary: A Ferguson convenience store that was looted and burned after the fatal shooting of Michael Brown will be rebuilt as a job training center.

entry.title: Looted Ferguson store to be transformed into training center
Ferguson shooting: no arrests yet as police continue hunt for gunman
entry.summary:
Ferguson: Nearly 48 hours after two officers were shot in racially charged Ferguson, Missouri, investigators had dozens of leads but no arrests to report in the hunt for the gunman.

One protester stood opposite the Ferguson police department with a sign "Cops Lives Matter," playing on the "Black Lives Matter" slogan that sprang up in the wake of the deaths of Mr Brown and an unarmed black man in New York City.

Mr Belmar, who leads the force in the Missouri county where Ferguson is located, said donations for rewards to help the investigation had poured in over the last two days.

entry.title: Ferguson shooting: no arrests yet as police continue hunt for gunman
Giuliani blames Obama for Ferguson shootings, other unrest
As Ferguson manhunt grinds on, leaders aim to defuse tension
entry.summary:
A police officer's helmet lies on the ground splashed with blood in Ferguson.

Thursday's shooting took place a week after the release of a US Justice Department report that appeared to vindicate long-standing complaints of pervasive racial bias leveled against Ferguson's mostly white police force.

entry.title: As Ferguson manhunt grinds on, leaders aim to defuse tension
entry.summary:
Chaunte Williams, 13, holds up three candles as she takes part in a vigil on Thursday in Ferguson.

Activists, condemning the wounding of the officers, held a candle-light prayer vigil for peace in Ferguson late on Thursday.

entry.title: Barack Obama Reads Mean Tweets, Talks Ferguson Shootings on 'Kimmel'
Calm prevails in Ferguson after shooting of police officers
entry.summary:
Only a few dozen protesters gathered that night outside Ferguson's police station - the nexus of many demonstrations.

Rasheen Aldridge, a 20-year-old regular at the protests, considers Ferguson his generation's civil-rights movement.

"This is the new time to make changes," added Aldridge, also a member of the Ferguson Commission, a group tasked by Missouri's governor to address underlying social and economic problems.

Protesters gather across the street from the Ferguson Police Department, Thursday, March 12, 2015, in Ferguson, Mo.

entry.title: Calm Prevails in Ferguson After Shooting of Police Officers
entry.summary: Two police officers were shot early Thursday morning in front of the Ferguson Police Department during a protest following the resignation of the city's police chief in the wake of damning U.S. Justice Department report.

entry.title: Calls for calm as the hunt continues for Ferguson shooter
entry.summary: Tensions have been high in Ferguson since August and escalated in November after a grand jury declined to prosecute officer Darren Wilson for Brown's killing.

entry.title: Manhunt Is Underway After Police Officers Are Shot in Ferguson
entry.summary: In a statement, the City of Ferguson said it was "diligently working to make systematic changes necessary to instill confidence," but added, "We cannot continue to move forward under threats of violence and destruction."

entry.title: Shot Ferguson police officers released from US hospital
entry.summary: Police take cover after two officers were shot while standing guard in front of the Ferguson Police Station.

entry.title: Obama banters with Kimmel, reflects on Ferguson
entry.summary: During a more subdued segment, Obama reflected on Wednesday night's shooting of two police officers in racially tense Ferguson, Missouri, just days after he had delivered a speech on racial healing in Selma, Alabama.

entry.title: News24.com | Obama: No excuse for criminal acts in Ferguson, Missouri
entry.summary:
The shooting of two police officers at a protest in Ferguson, which has been the center of a debate over race and policing, triggered a manhunt for suspects and increased tensions in the city.

"What had been happening in Ferguson was oppressive and objectionable and was worthy of protest," Obama said during an appearance on the ABC programme "Jimmy Kimmel Live."

entry.title: Obama banters with Kimmel, reflects on Ferguson
Obama banters with Kimmel, reflects on Ferguson
entry.summary: "What had been happening in Ferguson was oppressive and objectionable and was worthy of protest, but there was no excuse for criminal acts," he said.

entry.title: Video captures exact moment two police officers were shot last night in Ferguson
entry.summary:
The shots were fired shortly after midnight as protesters were gathered following the resignation of embattled Ferguson Police Chief Thomas Jackson on Wednesday.

The protest was a familiar scene in Ferguson, which saw similar and much larger demonstrations after the shooting death of black 18-year-old Michael Brown last summer by city police officer Darren Wilson.

In addition to Jackson, Ferguson's court clerk was fired last week and two police officers resigned.

entry.title: 2 officers shot at protest outside Ferguson police station
entry.summary: Belmar spoke about the two officers shot, one from the St. Louis County police department and one from Webster Groves, in front of the Ferguson Police Department early Thursday as demonstrators gathered.

entry.summary: But the Justice Department also said last week that Ferguson's police and court systems functioned as a money-making enterprise that heightened tensions among residents.

entry.title: Ferguson city manager leaving in response to DOJ report
entry.summary:
Ferguson City Council voted unanimously at a meeting on Tuesday to accept the resignation of City Manager John Shaw effective immediately.

The Justice Department launched its investigation into Ferguson's police department and municipal court after the Aug. 9 shooting death of unarmed black teenager Michael Brown by a white police officer.

entry.title: Ferguson city manager out after Justice Department report
entry.summary: Since Brown's death seven months ago, Mayor James Knowles has been the public face and voice of Ferguson's city government.

entry.title: Ferguson cited for not submitting traffic-stop race data
entry.summary:
"I believe that the city of Ferguson has the resolve to overcome the challenges it faces in the coming months and emerge as a stronger community for it," Shaw, 39, said in a statement included with the release.

Shaw had been Ferguson's city manager for eight years.

Online biographies indicate that he grew up in north St. Louis County and lived in Ferguson before working for the city.

entry.title: Missouri Supreme Court Appoints New Judge to Oversee Ferguson
entry.summary: "Extraordinary action is warranted in Ferguson, but the Court also is examining reforms that are needed on a statewide basis."

entry.title: News24.com | Missouri judge appointed to take over Ferguson court
entry.summary:
Ferguson Municipal Judge Ronald J Brockmeyer resigned on Monday, saying through a spokesperson that he was stepping down to promote public confidence in the court and help Ferguson "begin its healing process."

The federal report also cited several instances in which Ferguson's municipal judge, court clerk or city prosecutor helped "fix" tickets for colleagues and friends.

entry.title: Ferguson judge named in DOJ report resigns
entry.summary: "Mr. Brockmeyer recognizes that the Department of Justice report, as well as recent media reports, regardless of their accuracy or validity, have diminished the public's confidence in the Ferguson Municipal Court."

entry.title: Missouri appeals judge appointed to take over Ferguson court
entry.summary: The Missouri Supreme Court said it is assigning state appeals Judge Roy L. Richter to hear all of Ferguson's pending and future municipal court cases.

entry.title: Ferguson PD chief still in, but two veteran commanders out
entry.summary:
Meanwhile, three Ferguson employees implicated in racist emails exposed by that report are now gone from their jobs, the mayor said.

But Ferguson city spokesman Jeff Small identified one of the employees as court clerk Mary Ann Twitty, who was fired.

entry.title: Obama criticizes Ferguson as city seeks settlement over racial bias
entry.summary: Ferguson Mayor James Knowles said three city workers who demonstrated "egregious racial bias" are no longer employed by the city, and said Ferguson officials are pursuing other reforms to try to reach a settlement with the U.S. Justice Department.

entry.title: Obama: Racial bias within Ferguson police not isolated
entry.summary: The president made his first remarks about this week's Justice Department report of racial bias in Ferguson, which found officers routinely discriminating against blacks by using excessive force.

entry.title: Obama: Racial bias in Ferguson police dept. not isolated
entry.summary:
Ferguson city leaders are to meet with Justice Department officials in about two weeks to put forth an improvement plan.

He said other police departments should understand the intensity of feelings across the federal government in terms of making sure what's transpired in Ferguson doesn't happen elsewhere, although he called the Ferguson bias "an anomaly."

entry.title: Obama: Racial bias in Ferguson police dept. not isolated
entry.summary: In his most expansive comments yet about the Justice Department's report on bias against blacks in Ferguson, Obama said it was striking that investigators merely had to look at email sent by police officials to find evidence.

entry.title: Michael Brown's family to file civil lawsuit against Ferguson

entry.title: US finds racist, profit-driven practices in Ferguson

About 30 protesters braved sub-freezing weather Wednesday night to gather outside Ferguson's police station.

It also found Ferguson relies heavily on fines for petty offenses, such as jaywalking, to raise revenue.

entry.title: At least two protesters arrested in Ferguson hours after U.S. report
US finds racist, profit-driven practices in Ferguson
entry.summary:
At the very least, experts said Thursday, Ferguson must move quickly, and publicly, to prove it is serious about regaining public trust.

Most of Ferguson's police officers and city leaders are white, but two-thirds of the 21,000 residents are black.

Messages seeking comment from Ferguson Mayor James Knowles III and attorneys for Wilson were not returned.

"The chief has no credibility," said state Sen. Maria Chappelle-Nadal, a Democrat who represents Ferguson.

At a brief news conference Wednesday, the mayor tried to show that Ferguson is serious about reform, saying the city has been working for some time to find more black officers.

entry.title: At least two protesters arrested in Ferguson hours after U.S. report
entry.summary: Brown's killing touched off a national debate on race, led to months of street protests and amplified long-standing complaints in Ferguson and across the country of police harassment and mistreatment of minorities.

entry.title: Ferguson policies targeted blacks, created toxic environment: U.S. attorney general
entry.summary: The report reviewed the city's records and found that in a city where blacks make up about two-thirds of the population, they accounted for 85 percent of the total charges brought by Ferguson police, and more than 90 percent of arrests.

entry.title: Ferguson employee fired, 2 others on leave over emails
entry.summary:
(AP) - Ferguson Mayor James Knowles says one police department employee was fired and two others are on administrative leave over racist emails uncovered in a Justice Department investigation into the city's law enforcement practices.

Knowles' comments at a press conference Wednesday were the first response from city leaders to the federal investigation that found systemic racial bias in law enforcement in the St. Louis suburb of Ferguson.

entry.title: Feds: Evidence backs Ferguson officer's account in shooting
entry.summary: Wilson first encountered Brown and his friend, Dorian Johnson, walking in the middle of a Ferguson street, just minutes after a report of a robbery at a nearby convenience store.

entry.title: U.S. won't prosecute Ferguson officer in Michael Brown shooting
entry.summary: The report issued Wednesday said blacks in Ferguson are disproportionately subject to excessive police force, baseless traffic stops and citations for infractions as petty as walking down the middle of the street.

entry.title: In Ferguson, scathing Justice Department report brings pressure for change

entry.title: In Ferguson, scathing US report brings pressure for change
entry.summary:
In pairing the announcements, the Obama administration sought to offset community disappointment over the conclusion that the shooting of Michael Brown was legally justified with a message of hope for Ferguson's majority-black citizens.

"It is not difficult to imagine how a single tragic incident set off the city of Ferguson like a powder keg," Holder said.

Ferguson Mayor James Knowles III said the city had cooperated with the Justice Department and has made some changes, including a diversity training program for city employees.

entry.title: Ferguson reviewing federal report on police force
U.S. report finds racial bias in Ferguson Police Dept.
entry.summary: The racial disparity in those statistics was so stark that the Justice Department has concluded in a report scheduled for release Wednesday that there was only one explanation: The Ferguson Police Department was routinely violating the constitutional rights of its black residents.

entry.title: Justice Department finds racial bias in Ferguson police practices
entry.summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The U.S. Justice Department has concluded that the Ferguson, Missouri, police department routinely engages in racially biased practices, a law enforcement official familiar with the department's findings said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Racist Obama joke revealed in scathing Justice Department report on 'biased' Ferguson police practices
entry.summary:
A Justice Department investigation has found patterns of racial bias in the Ferguson police department and at the municipal jail and court.

The department will use the findings to negotiate policy changes with Ferguson officials and enter a consent decree, or to sue the city to force change.

Civil rights attorney Jerryl Christmas, who has represented people who have clashed with Ferguson police and city officials, said he was not surprised by the findings, and he hopes to see Ferguson Police Chief Tom Jackson fired.

entry.title: U.S. Justice Department finds racial bias in Ferguson police practices
entry.summary:
But they are unlikely to restore full trust in the Ferguson police by citizens who were angered when a grand jury decided not to indict Brown's killer, officer Darren Wilson.

The official said that in Ferguson's court system, African-Americans were less likely to have their cases dismissed by a municipal judge and made up 95 percent of people held longer than two days in the Ferguson jail.

entry.title: Justice Department finds racial bias in Ferguson police practices
entry.summary: The investigation into the police department began in August after the shooting of unarmed African-American teen Michael Brown by a white police officer in Ferguson sparked national protests.

entry.title: Ferguson officials to meet with Justice Department
entry.summary:
John Gaskin III, a St. Louis community activist, praised the findings, saying, "Ferguson police have to see the light in how they deal with people of color.

Associated Press writers Jim Salter and Jim Suhr in St. Louis and Alan Scher Zagier in Ferguson contributed to this report.

entry.title: Ferguson officials to meet with Justice Department
entry.summary:
FILE - In this Nov. 26, 2014, file photo, nembers of Missouri National Guard stand outside of the Ferguson Police Department and the Municipal Court in Ferguson, Mo.

Overall, African-Americans make up 67 percent of the population of Ferguson, about 10 miles north of downtown St. Louis.

entry.title: Upcoming DOJ Ferguson Findings Likely To Reveal No Criminal Charges For Darren Wilson
entry.summary:
The shooting touched off weeks of "hands up, don't shoot" protests in the streets of Ferguson and other cities.

Along with the police chokehold death of a New York City man suspected of selling untaxed cigarettes and the December killings of two New York police officers, the Ferguson case became part of a national conversation about race and policing.

entry.title: Ferguson News Guide: No charges expected for policeman
entry.summary: Holder has repeatedly signaled that federal officials have identified problems with the Ferguson Police Department.

entry.title: Department of Justice to criticize Ferguson police in report due soon: NY Times
entry.summary:
Attorney General Eric Holder said after visiting Ferguson last year that many black residents expressed mistrust and fear of police.

The final report could lead to a civil rights suit against Ferguson police unless officials are able to reach a settlement with the Justice Department, The New York Times said.

entry.title: Ferguson police levied excessive traffic fines on blacks ? DOJ leak
entry.summary: For those too poor to pay their tickets, routine traffic stops in Ferguson could end up in repeated imprisonment due to mounting fines.

entry.title: Report to criticize Ferguson police for discriminatory practices
entry.summary:
The report, which is expected to be released as early as this week, will force Ferguson officials to either negotiate a settlement with the Justice Department or face being sued on civil rights charges.

Either way, the result is likely to be significant changes inside the Ferguson Police Department, which is at the center of a national debate over race and policing.

Investigators do not need to prove Ferguson's policies are racially motivated or that the police intentionally singled out minorities.

entry.title: Prosecutor Defends Ferguson Police Shooting Inquiry
Ferguson officials: No word on federal investigations
Justice Department likely to sue Ferguson police department: report
entry.summary: Speaking at the National Press Club Tuesday, Attorney General Eric Holder said he expects to announce the results of the department's Ferguson investigation before he leaves office.

entry.title: Justice Dept. examining Ferguson racial discrimination
entry.summary:
CNN reported the Justice Department is preparing to bring a lawsuit against Ferguson if the police department does not make changes.

In August, Ferguson was thrust into the limelight when white police officer Darren Wilson shot and killed unarmed black teen Michael Brown.

entry.title: Justice Department May Sue Ferguson Police Over Racial Bias
